Award.AwardTitle: Using a Viral Protein to Study the Functional Organization of ER-mitochondrial Membrane Contacts and Trafficking Across this Compartment

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT
Membrane contacts between the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and mitochondria, known as mitochondria-associated membranes (MAM) are communication hubs that play crucial roles in diverse cellular functions, including ER to mitochondrial calcium (Ca2+) signaling, mitochondrial bioenergetics, lipid exchange, innate immunity, and apoptosis. The MAM is now emerging as a site for ER to mitochondrial trafficking of cellular proteins and viral proteins. This project characterizes a cytomegalovirus (CMV) protein, known as UL37 exon 1 protein (pUL37x1) that targets the MAM, alters some of its functions, and traffics from the ER to mitochondria. This project will examine how proteins use the MAM to traffic from the ER to mitochondria. It is projected that CMV pUL37x1 trafficking uses MAM vesicular or tether mediated mechanisms to traffic to mitochondria. This project will test whether MAM tethers or vesicular components underlie ER to mitochondrial trafficking using complementary approaches of inhibition (siRNAs, knock out cells, dominant negative mutants, and chemical inhibitors) and overexpression of MAM tether or MAM vesicular pathway components.

BROADER IMPACTS
These studies will impact the intracellular protein trafficking field, as well as education and society (technology development). The project aims to understand MAM organization and its regulation, which affects cellular physiology and responses. The use of multifocal structured illumination microscopy (MSIM) will advance the intracellular protein trafficking field and, more broadly, cellular imaging. The studies will include training of undergraduate researchers, and in particular will continue to support the efforts of the participating labs in training underrepresented minorities in science. Because of the multidisciplinary approaches employed in this project, students will benefit from training in confocal live cell imaging, MSIM imaging, and molecular virology and biochemical approaches, participating in scientific discussions, and presenting their work at scientific meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our major goal for this grant was to understand the organization, the functional domains and the regulation of contact sites between two subcellular organelles: the endoplasmic reticulum and mitochondria.  These sites, known as mitochondria associated membranes, are important because they permit communication between these organelles and, ultimately, affect cell metabolism and cell survival.  It has recently been documented that some cellular proteins traffic from the endoplasmic reticulum to mitochondria.  Surprisingly little information is known about the role of these contact sites in protein trafficking from the endoplasmic reticulum to mitochondria. For these studies, we used a cytomegalovirus protein, known as viral mitochondria-localized inhibitor of apoptosis, which traffics to these contact sites and then to mitochondria. In collaboration with Dr. George Patterson (National Institutes of Health) we used multiple emergent superresolution microscopy technologies, including multifocal structured illumination microscopy, stimulated emission depletion, and photoactivated localization microscopy, to study trafficking of the viral protein from the endoplasmic reticulum and its organization at the outer mitochondrial membrane. We assessed various cellular mechanisms in trafficking of a cytomegalovirus protein from the endoplasmic reticulum to mitochondria. Further, we were able to study its organization at the outer mitochondrial membrane and found that the viral protein organizes in nanometric clusters that can be visualized by superresolution imaging but not by conventional confocal microscopy.  Some of these studies have already been published and these have advanced the understanding of endoplasmic reticulum to mitochondrial trafficking pathway, organization of proteins at the mitochondrial surface, and more broadly the use of superresolution cellular imaging. 

 

Our studies included trainees including high school, undergraduate and graduate researchers as well as junior faculty in the research. We trained the researchers in laboratory technologies as well as in presentation skills and interpretation of experimental results. Because of our multidisciplinary team, the trainees benefited from mentorship in diverse fields including live cell imaging (Dr. Jaiswal), superresolution imaging (Dr. Patterson), and biochemical approaches (Dr. Colberg-Poley).

 

We trained three undergraduate (from the University of Maryland and Pennsylvania State University), a medical (George Washington University), two Master’s (George Washington University) and one doctoral (George Washington University) students with this funding. We familiarized a college instructor (Trinity Washington University) with current state-of-the-art technologies. Our trainees were integral in generating the data for publications that have resulted from this work.

 

Highlights of Broader Impacts achieved through this NSF funding:

 

(1) Advancing technologies including:

(2) Team collaboration with a Federal laboratory (G. Patterson NIH lab)

(3) Public outreach (Viruses Book on Cytomegalovirus Research, Cytomegalovirus Public Health & Policy Conference)
